name: GroupManagementTool
tagline: Selfservice portal for group management in Active Directory
body:
### Welcome to Group Management Tool

This free self service portal provides your users in Active Directory an easy way to manage 'their' groups.
Only 3 steps are required to maintain group members. 

![main-page](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11002556/7445281/cab16c10-f1de-11e4-8fa4-157ce3556fe7.png)

## Introduction
In a normal Active Directory environment permissions to resources are controlled by groups and their membership. Simply speaking, a user member of a particular group has permission to a particular resource. 
If a user needs access to a resource the IT department will be contacted which then fulfills the request. 

In a small environment it only takes a few steps. In bigger companies the it might take several steps more to solve a user's request (Ticket processing, approval handling, etc.).

This tool helps out. It gives a user a way to update the membership of a group that she is been trusted in 3 steps without contacting IT. - Time saving for the user and for the IT department!


## From user's perspective
1. A user opens Internet Explorer and navigates to the URL under which the tool has been published. E.g. http://groupmanagementtool. The user will be authenticated through windows authentication without keying in password and sees directly which groups she is able to manage:

Members of the first group will be shown automatically. 

2. Members can be deleted by selecting and choosing the delete link. Alternatively new users can be added to the group by typing in a few characters of the new user's name or UserID and adding him with the add-link:

3. Last the changes must be committed by clicking the updated-membership link:

A status message will inform if the action succeeded or failed.

As 'goody' the pint link on the top of the page will sent the group membership of the present displayed group to the user.

## From IT's perspective
1. Locate the group you like to delegate to the user / or a user group in Active Directory
2. Select the tab 'MangedBy' and specify the user / or user group which should be able to manage the group.
3. Check the 'Manager can update membership' checkbox and safe the changes.

Usual security or distribution groups can bee chosen. Not tested are dynamic distribution lists. 

As 'goody' the tool provides a list of all groups which have the 'managedBy' plus 'Manager can update membership' checked as overview. The e-mail button will sent the displayed page to you.
